html:
Following our previous visit to Two Street Studio, we are moving our Meet Your Next Employer series to Salt Lake City this week to explore the work of Feldman Architecture.

Founded by Jonathan Feldman in 2003, the architecture and interior studio describes its mission as to “honor the spirit of each site and champion regenerative practices for a better future.” Headquartered in San Francisco, the firm looking to “quickly and meaningfully expand in the Intermountain West region.”

Over on Archinect Jobs, the firm is currently hiring for a Senior Job Captain from the Intermountain West. For candidates interested in applying for a position or anybody interested in learning more about the firm’s output, we have rounded up five homes by Feldman Architecture that exemplify the firm’s ethos.

The Phoenix, Healdsburg, CA

Situated atop a ridge in Healdsburg, California, The Phoenix was designed to capture long views of the valley and Mount Saint Helena. Designed as a response to the loss of the original home in a 2017 fire, the project reconsiders site placement and seeks to integrate the structure into its surrounding landscape. 

The scheme consists of elongated, rectilinear forms stretching east to west, improving connections between indoor and outdoor spaces. A relocated pool enhances spatial continuity, while sliding glass doors and custom casework frame views. A lighting installation by studio DRIFT introduces a dynamic element within the minimalist interior.

Surf House, Santa Cruz, CA

Surf House is a coastal residence in Santa Cruz, designed to integrate with its natural surroundings while adhering to site constraints, including a 100-year geologic setback and California Coastal Commission regulations. Positioned as a windbreak, the home maximizes ocean views from the rear yard and deck while creating a sheltered front courtyard. 

Locally sourced Monterey Cypress cladding, provided by Arborica, weathers naturally and unifies the exterior and interior palette. Large openings connect indoor and outdoor living spaces, with an upper-level transition to plaster finishes. “Thoughtfully placed windows weave surprising glimpses of blues and greens into the earth-toned interior finishes,” the firm adds.

The Sanctuary, Palo Alto, CA

Designed for a couple looking to downsize and plan for retirement, The Sanctuary also sought to preserve the site’s natural landscape. Positioned behind a heritage oak tree, the home integrates architecture with its surroundings through a series of courtyards and view gardens.

The structure is elevated on piers to protect tree roots, with cantilevered balconies blurring indoor and outdoor spaces. Three pavilions span the deep lot, including a second-story rental apartment. Board-formed concrete walls define interior spaces, complemented by Alaskan yellow cedar, creating a refined yet natural aesthetic that emphasizes landscape over built form.

The Meadow Home, Portola Valley, CA

Situated on a grassy knoll, the Meadow Home comprises an L-shaped structure following the land’s contours to minimize its visual impact. The main wing features an open-plan kitchen, dining, and living area with floor-to-ceiling glass doors that connect to an expansive patio, framing views of the surrounding prairie. 

Splayed concrete walls direct sightlines toward Windy Hill, while a green roof extends the meadow over the garage. Cedar siding, stained warm grey, and a sleek black roof create a balance between rural character and modern architectural expression.

Butterfly House, Carmel, CA

Located in the Santa Lucia Preserve near Carmel, California, the Butterfly House is designed as a retreat for retirement and family visits, integrating with its natural surroundings. The home consists of three pavilions, each topped with butterfly roofs that capture views, extend living spaces outdoors, and collect rainwater for irrigation. 

The central pavilion contains shared living areas, while the other two house private spaces for sleeping and relaxation. A neutral material palette of concrete, glass, steel, and plywood enhances indoor-outdoor continuity. Passive heating, daylighting, and a concealed solar array contribute to the home’s energy efficiency and sustainability.
